results.title: The General. - [Edited version]
results.creator_credit: Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Film Classics
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the Motion Picture”.
An edited version of Clyde Bruckman and Buster Keaton’s 1926 comedy feature, showing Buster Keaton in his most successful period as an actor and director of this satire on Civil War espionage. Combines good examples of Keaton’s dry wit and acute sense of timing. This edited work, narrated by Paul Killiam, indicates the significance of ‘The General’ in film history.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Saul J. Turell, Paul Killiam and Film Classics

results.title: The General Assembly
results.creator_credit: United Nations Films, V.R. Sarma and Krishna Singh
results.brief_description: Traces the history of the United Nations General Assembly and describes its efforts to promote human welfare and peace among the peoples of the world. Surveys the organisation of the General Assembly, areas of jurisdiction, and the work of committees. Includes scenes of an annual session as delegates and visitors arrive. Narrated by Michael Rennie.
results.creator_credit_for_label: United Nations Films, V.R. Sarma and Krishna Singh

results.title: The General
results.creator_credit: Joseph Schenck, Buster Keaton Productions, Buster Keaton and Clyde Bruckman
results.brief_description:
Keaton, an engine driver, recaptures his train and rescues his girl after it has been stolen and she has been kidnapped by Union soldiers from behind Confederate lines. Based on an actual incident in the Civil War this is widely regarded as Keaton’s finest film. Oblivious to the dictates of normal comprehension, Keaton as Johnny its own.

Credits: Producer, Joseph M. Schenck ; directors, Buster Keaton, Clyde Bruckmann ; writers, Al Boasberg, Charles Smith ; photography, J. Devereaux Jennings, Bert Haines ; piano accompaniment, William Perry.
Cast: Buster Keaton, Marion Mack, Glen Cavander.

results.title: The Gay rock and roll years
results.creator_credit: Clare Beavan, Shauna Brown, BBC and Fulcrum
results.brief_description: A history of the anglo-saxon gay and lesbian movement scored to the liberating popular tunes of the last 25 years. Moving from the initial struggle for gay law reform, to the revolutionary politics spurned by Stonewall to the homophobic policies initiated under Thatcher and the New Right, this film is a celebration of the achievements and struggles of gay and lesbian activists. Funny, inspiring and bound to get your feet tapping “The Gay Rock and Roll Years” is a great introduction to queer history. Songs featured include Doris Day singing “Secret Love”, The Kinks doing “Lola”, Sylvester singing “You Make Me feel (Mighty Real) and Culture Club asking “Do You Really Want To Hurt Me?”. From rockabilly to soul to glam to disco to punk to house: we’re gay, we’re proud, we don’t ever stop the dance.

results.title: The Gathering drum
results.creator_credit: D. Keith Carlson and WGBH Educational Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Kindergarten child series”.
At the beginning of the kindergarten day children are encouraged to move freely and choose from a variety of play objects. A drumbeat then brings them together to be introduced to the day’s activities.

results.title: The Gas turbine
results.creator_credit: Shell Film Unit and Peter De Normanville
results.brief_description: The gas turbine is a heat engine, the simplest and smoothest running yet devised. All heat engines burn fuel, change a small part of the heat produced into energy, and waste the rest through the exhaust. In the gas turbine, rushing torrent of hot high-pressure exhaust gas is the turbine’s source of power.

results.title: The Gary Crew video
results.creator_credit: Christine McCaul Gleitzman, Mark Waters and Insight Profile
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Insight profile”.
Gary Crew explains how he developed the ideas behind his award winning novels. He takes you back through his childhood and early life to the buildings and landscapes which were the inspiration for the settings of many of his books. He explains how the right ‘setting’ for a novel is as important as a good storyline, and how to develop any place, no matter how boring, into something special.

results.title: The Garden of Gujurat
results.creator_credit: Ezra Mir, Documentary Films of India, UNICEF and Mohan Wadhwani
results.brief_description: More than 20,000 farmers and their families were eking a bare existence in the Kaira District of India. Through a modern milk plant, contstructed with the co-operation of UNICEF, the Food and Agriculture Organisation, the Government of India, New Zealand (under the Colombo Plan) and their own co-operative, scores of communities are benefiting, as well as the thousands of school children who are receiving daily rations of safe milk.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ezra Mir, Documentary Films of India, UNICEF and Mohan Wadhwani

results.title: The Garden
results.creator_credit: James MacKay, Channel 4, Screen Arts, Basilisk Productions and Derek Jarman
results.brief_description: The Garden is rich with metaphor. The Garden of Eden and the Garden of Gethsemane. In the garden is visible the whole sensual cycle of life and death. We watch the Passion enacted by two male lovers, filmed in the garden Jarman himself created and retreated within to prepare for his own battle with mortality. In “The Garden” the spirit and the flesh, sin and redemption, are united. Like Pasolini, Jarman eschews classic narrative for the pleasures of a cinema of poetry and seeks a spirituality based on eros rather than repression. A difficult, maddening, wondrous film. With the glorious Tilda Swinton.

results.title: The Gap
results.brief_description: From dawn one morning until dawn the next day, a man in deep despair tries to end his life by jumping off “The Gap”, a cliff at the mouth of the Sydney Harbour. The entrance is one of mixed and dichotomous meanings, as it is the gateway to a majestic city as well as a place of unutterable sadness where people go to die. Two cops are sent to talk him down. The man outdoes them in his dignity and his courage.
